text.p: In this article, we provide a framework for determining when it is optimal to move when labor market opportunities are declining. We model the decision to migrate as akin to owning a financial option in which the exercise price is the fixed cost of moving. We show that a higher fixed cost associated with moving and a higher standard deviation of the quality of the labor market reduce the incentive to migrate. We then empirically examine whether the standard deviation of indicators of labor market quality reduce the likelihood of migration. Our findings strongly support this hypothesis, and imply that for the relatively mobile population of high- skilled workers the counterfactual outmigration rates that would obtain if future labor-market quality were known with certainty are more than twice observed rates.

The share of workers employed in manufacturing has been declining as the mid-20th century (ON. Fisher 2004). Amidst this transition, one often reads stories about small towns with econo- mies that have been devastated by the loss of a local factory and the struggles of the workers who have been left behind to maintain a lower standard of living. For example, a recent article in the New York Times describes the town of Port Clinton, Ohio:

The manufacturing foundation of Port Clintons modest prosperity in the 1950s and 1960s began to tremble in the 1970s. The big Standard Products factory at the east end of town pro- vided nearly 1000 steady, good-paying blue-collar jobs in the 1950s, but the payroll was more than halved in the 1970s. After two more decades of layoffs and "give backs," the plant gates on Maple Street finally closed in 1993, leaving a barbed-wire-encircled ruin now graced with Environmental Protection Agency warnings of toxicity. But that was merely the most visible symbol of the towns economic implosion.

Manufacturing employment in Ottawa County plummeted from 55% of all jobs in 1965 to 25% in 1995 and kept falling. By 2012, the average worker in Ottawa County had not had a real raise for four decades and, in fact, is now paid roughly 16% less in inflation-adjusted dollars than his or her grandfather in the early 1970s (Putnam 2013).
Another example can be found in a recent article in the Washington Post about Decatur, Tennessee:

Today, although, all traces of the Decaturville Sportswear plant, which once used some 1500 locals, have vanished, and nothing comparable has replaced it. The unemployment rate is higher in Decatur County now than it was when Clinton took office. One out of every four resi- dents use food stamps. . .

. . .Decatur County has just under 12,000 residents. About 800 of them live in Decaturville, the county seat. The countys unemployment rate has doubled, to 9%, from where it was at the end of the Clinton administration. Factory employment has been cut in half since 2000. Fewer peo- ple had jobs in the county last year than in 2001 (Tankersley 2015).

In light of such stories, it is natural to ask when it becomes optimal to migrate away from labor markets experiencing declining quality in search of better opportunities elsewhere. Dating back to Sjaastad (1962), the traditional view is that migration is akin to an investment to be made if the value of the benefits of increased labor market opportunities available elsewhere outweigh the fixed costs associated with migrating. These costs, which reflect both direct moving expenses and the psychological costs of leaving friends and family behind, are often considerable. We agree with this perspective. Given the important nature of fixed costs, however, we believe that the investment literature can inform analysis of the migration decision even more deeply. The literature on real options associated with investment implies that when a firm faces a substantial fixed cost, the firms investment decision is to determine the optimal point in time to undertake the investment. 1 In this article, we argue that the decision to move to a new location in search of

better job opportunities is akin to this investment decision by firms. For workers, the choice is to decide how long they should remain in a location in which the quality of economic opportunities is declining. In this type of economic environment, the decision to move is akin to owning a financial option-the worker has the option, but not the obligation, to move at any point in time. The prob- lem for the worker is to determine the optimal point in time to exercise this option. The worker must choose this point in time to move with the understanding that one can only leave their cur- rent location once and that exercising the option requires bearing the fixed costs associated with moving. We develop an investment theory of migration in which the greater the degree of uncertainty about the quality of future labor-market opportunities, the longer the individual will wait before moving. The intuition for this result is that, even when the economic opportunities available to the worker are declining over time, in a world with uncertainty there is some probability that these opportunities will be greater next period. Nonetheless, if economic opportunities are decreasing on average over time, there eventually comes a point at which it is no longer optimal for the worker to wait to observe next periods labor market shock. At that point, the worker would be better off moving than holding on to the option. We then examine this hypothesis empirically, estimating a series of models that relate outmi- gration to measures of the level and volatility of local labor-market quality during the Great Recession. Regardless of how we measure quality, we find that volatility causes substantial declines in the rate of migration out of local labor markets. We take several steps, including con- trolling for prerecession outmigration and instrumenting for quality using a widely accepted tech- nique due to Bartik (1991), to address the possibility that endogeneity or simultaneity explain the relationship that we identify between volatility and outmigration; our findings are robust to these noncausal interpretations. Our estimates imply that average outmigration rates would be
1 For a textbook treatment of these types of problems, see Dixit and Pindyck (1994) and Stokey (2009).

substantially higher if people knew with certainty the quality that they would face if they remained in their current labor markets. For higher-skilled workers, whom previous research (Wozniak 2010; Cadena and Kovak 2016) has shown relatively mobile, the counterfactual rates that would obtain if outmigration were not inhibited by volatility would be more than double observed rates, on average. This article extends the human-investment theory of migration originated by Sjaastad (1962), who argued that net in-migration is likely to occur in locations in which the present dis- counted value of expected wages is high relative to other locations. Subsequent research used search-theoretic models to address imperfect information across locations (e.g., Rogerson [1982]; Gordon and Vickerman [1982]; Maier [1985]; Berninghaus and Seifort-Vogt [1991]). For example, individuals considering moving to a new location might lack information about the current oppor- tunities available in other locations. The search-theoretic models imply that those considering moving should use searching as a way of discovering such opportunities. This implies that there is a speculative motive to migration. Later work, however, emphasizes the role of future uncertainty. For example, Burda (1993) appeals to the early literature on the option theory of investment to make predictions regarding migration. He notes that there is uncertainty about expected future outcomes in for- eign locations. The greater the uncertainty about those expected future outcomes, the longer (on average) an individual will wait before deciding to migrate. OConnell (1997) extends this work to develop a formal model of migration and return migration. The benefit of his model is that it allows for the analysis of both the speculative motive for migration and the incentive to wait discussed in Burda (1993).

Our model, although similar to this more recent strand of research, differs in that we assume that individuals take opportunities in other locations as given. This allows us to focus on the con- ditions in the current, observable labor market and the uncertainty about the quality therein. We do this because the motivation for our article is to understand why migration is so infrequent even when local labor-market quality is in relative decline. This is in contrast to Burda (1993) and OConnell (1997), who focus on uncertainty about wages in foreign locations. 3 In addition, we

consider the value associated with the overall quality of the labor market, rather than just expected wage differentials. Consistent with Burda (1993) and OConnell (1997), the model generates the prediction that greater uncertainty about the future implies that the individual should wait. How- ever, as our focus is on uncertainty about the quality of local labor market conditions, the main contribution of our model is that it generates the specific, testable hypothesis that areas with greater variation in labor market quality should experience less out-migration. In this respect, our article takes up the challenge put forth by OConnell (1997) to empirically examine the role of uncertainty in migration decisions.
2 A somewhat related article is Anam, Chiang, and Hua (2008), who examine the decision-making of a family rather

than an individual. Their model provides a motive for some family members to move to diversify the risk of the family. 3 OConnell (1997) features return migration, but the uncertainty is always about the wage in what is initially the foreign
location. 4 Note that OConnell (1997) solves for labor market equilibrium and finds that the option value of migration is zero. If

our model was only a model of wage differentials, we could assume that the decision to migrate has an incremental effect on the wage differential. This would imply that in the limit as we approach a perfectly competitive labor market, the option value of migration would go to zero. However, our emphasis on labor market quality precludes this sort of assumption because we would need to know how an individuals migration decision affects not only the wage differen- tial, but other characteristics of the labor market as well such as relative unemployment rates.
John Gardner and Joshua R. Hendrickson

Our empirical findings suggest that our theoretical model has considerable power to explain why outmigration from areas experiencing relative declines is not more common. In addition, they shed new light on the longstanding, yet still somewhat puzzling, empirical regularity that internal migration is relatively uncommon, despite apparent arbitrage opportunities presented by spatial differences in labor-market conditions. Card (2001), for example, finds no evidence of outmigra- tion among natives in response to inflows of immigrants. Similarly, Cadena and Kovak (2016) find that internal migration is substantially less sensitive to employment shocks for U.S. natives than for foreign immigrants, potentially suggesting that natives choose to forgo the gains to be had from moving. Furthermore, in their empirical model of the relationship between expected income and migration, Kennan and Walker (2011) find that high moving costs must be invoked to rationalize the dearth of observed migrations. Our model, and the empirical evidence that sup- ports it, suggest that uncertainty about future labor-market quality may interact with moving costs, amplifying the effects of even modest disincentives to moving. Our results may also help explain long-run and cyclical trends in internal migration. For example, Saks and Wozniak (2011) document a secular decline in internal migration within the United States during the end of the 20th Century and examine several competing explanations for this trend; increases in local labor market volatility may help explain their findings. Investigating the sources of pro-cyclicality in internal migration, Molloy et al. (2011) show that national (that is, across-state) variation in employment measures does not explain aggregate rates of internal migra- tion within the United States. Our results, in contrast, suggest that within-labor-market increases in such variation are related to outmigration, and therefore may help explain the relationship between internal migration and the business cycle.

There are two important implications that one can draw from this condition. First, the partial derivative of the optimal stopping threshold with respect to moving costs is negative. Thus, the greater the cost of moving, the lower the quality of the labor market that an individual is willing to endure before moving. The second implication concerns the role of economic uncertainty. From Equation 7, the optimal stopping decision depends on a 1 . Note that from Equation 4 that a 1 depends on r. Com- parative statics are difficult to obtain analytically. In lieu of comparative statics, we plot the rela- tionship between q Ã and r in Figure 1 using a numerical example. As shown, the threshold

exhibits monotonic decay as r rises. This implies that the greater degree of uncertainty about future labor market quality, the longer individuals are willing to stay in their present location. The intuition is as follows. Even though the quality of the labor market is declining on average, over any given time interval there is a chance that the quality of the labor market improves. The magni- tude of such an improvement is proportional to r. Thus, a larger r implies a larger possible

improvement in the quality of the labor market over a given time interval. It is the possibility of a large improvement that gives the individual an incentive to wait. Consider the following example in which the quality of the labor market is measured by the unemployment rate. An individual worker observes the unemployment rate each period and deter- mines whether or not to move. As the unemployment rate rises, the quality of labor market oppor- tunities is declining. Eventually the unemployment rate will rise to a level at which the individual worker will realize that he or she is better off moving. Now consider this decision at the margin. As the worker observes the unemployment rate each period, the decision to move will be conditional on the workers expectations of the unem- ployment rate in the next period. A positive shock to the unemployment rate makes the individual worker more likely to move. A negative shock to the unemployment rate makes the worker more likely to stay. It is only when even the expectation of a negative shock to the unemployment rate is insufficient to justify waiting to observe the shock that the worker will ultimately move. It follows that, all else equal, the larger the volatility of the unemployment rate, the larger will be the size of the shock and the longer an individual worker will be willing to stay. Thus, the predictions of the model with regard to how individuals should respond to both the level and volatility of labor market quality produce two testable hypotheses. The first is that declines in labor market quality make an individual worker more likely to move from the present location. The second is that increases in the volatility of labor market quality give workers the incentive to stay in their present location longer. This first hypothesis is straightforward. As the

quality of labor market opportunities declines, workers eventually reach a point at which it is not worth staying and they seek better opportunities elsewhere. The second hypothesis, although prima facie counterintuitive, is a straightforward implication of the option approach. As it is always possible that there could be a positive shock to labor market quality next period, it might be beneficial to wait until next periods shock is revealed rather than pay the cost associated with moving. The larger the volatility of these shocks, the longer an individual worker should be willing to stay in their present location.
Identification Strategy, Data, and Variable Construction

The theoretical argument developed above suggests that migration out of local labor markets should respond to both the level and volatility of the quality of those markets. In particular, increasing volatility may slow the counterfactual rate of outmigration due to declining levels of labor market quality. To provide an empirical test of this theory, we estimate a series of models that relate outmigration behavior to measures of the level and volatility of local labor market quality.

Our measures of the quality and extent of migration out of local labor markets are based on Integrated Public Use Microdata Samples (IPUMS) of the American Community Survey (ACS) (Ruggles et al. 2015). 8 Our theoretical model makes predictions about the impact of the volatility

of labor-market quality when the level of that quality is decreasing, on average. To focus on the motivating question with which we introduce our article-the relationship between outmigration and labor-market quality during times of economic upheaval-and to increase the relevance of our findings for public policy, our primary sample, drawn at the height of the Great Recession, is the 2010 ACS. In parts of our analysis, we also use a 2006 ACS sample to control for pre-recession trends. Each annual IPUMS ACS sample represents 1% of the U.S. population, from which we retain observations on all working-age men (ages 16-64) who were not enrolled in school at the time of enumeration. Partially to focus on longer-range moves and partially to increase the sizes of our market-specific samples, we define local labor markets as three-digit metropolitan areas. Within a given metropolitan area, members of different skill groups may face different local labor-market quality. Furthermore, previous studies have shown that higher-skilled workers are more mobile (Wozniak, 2010; Cadena and Kovak, 2016). Accordingly, we stratify our samples into those with a high-school education or less and those with at least some college. This approach enables us to allow for skill differences in the outmigration response to local labor market quality while still constructing reasonably precise measures of those variables. We proxy for the level and volatility of quality using the area 3 skill-group 3 year sample means and standard deviations of unemployment, weeks worked, and annual income from wages. In constructing these statistics, we use the ACS definition of unemployment (which excludes labor-force nonparticipants) and average weeks worked and income over all observations not

Respondents to each ACS report the metropolitan areas where they lived both at the time of enumeration and during the prior year. When these metropolitan areas differ, we code respondents as outmigrants from the initial area and measure annual outmigration as the area-and skill-group-specific one-year outmigration rate.

Table 1 summarizes the key variables that we use in our empirical analysis. As the table shows, the Great Recession induced substantial variation in the level and volatility of labor market quality, increasing the national average standard deviation of unemployment and income, and decreasing that average for weeks worked, for both skill groups. At the same time, outmigration rates decreased for both skill groups during this period. The table also shows that, across periods, there are large between-skill-group differences in the volatility of labor-market quality. Figure 2, which plots estimated densities of skill-group-specific local labor-market volatility for 2010, dem- onstrates that there is significant dispersion in the volatility of each of our quality measures across local labor markets.

estimated partial effects of volatility may not translate to manifestly lower rates of migration out of relatively volatile local labor markets. Rather, our estimates should be viewed as decomposing the equi- librium relationship between outmigration and labor-market quality into coincident level and volatility effects. One threat to the causal interpretation of these estimates is the possibility that metro-level factors not included in the regressions affect both outmigration and labor-market volatility. Eco- nomic decline, for example, may cause greater outmigration and unemployment volatility, attenu- ating our estimates. Conversely, a relative boom may slow outmigration, increasing the size of the labor force, exacerbating volatility and, consequently, overstating the causal relationship between volatility and outmigration. Note however that in both of these examples the confounding vari- able is the level of labor-market quality, for which we proxy using mean quality measures them- selves. Thus, only factors that are correlated with volatility and outmigration but not our mean quality measures threaten the causal interpretation of the estimates. To the extent that such factors are correlated over time within local labor markets, we can proxy for them by including prerecession outmigration rates in our models. Note that a lagged dependent-variable structure is likely more appropriate to control for serially correlated unob- served heterogeneity in outmigration rates than a fixed-effects model, which implies monotone increasing or decreasing population (other things equal). The remaining columns of Table 2 pre- sent estimates of specifications that include lagged skill-specific local outmigration rates. For the high-skill group, the estimates do not suggest that our previous findings are a consequence of unobserved area-level confounders. For every quality measure, the coefficient on the standard deviation increases in absolute value when we include lagged outmigration in the model. 15 For the

low-skilled, the evidence is somewhat mixed. The coefficients on the standard deviations of unem- ployment and income remain negative, although insignificant, while the coefficient on the stan- dard deviation of weeks worked is no longer significantly positive. One explanation for this pattern is that conditioning on lagged migration leaves little variation in current migration for members of this less mobile group, although the possibility remains that there is greater endogene- ity between outmigration and labor-market volatility for less skilled workers.

Another potential threat to the causal interpretation of our estimates is that simultaneity may create a mechanical relationship between migration and labor-market volatility. Moreover, the direction of the resulting bias, which depends on whether the level and volatility faced by out- migrants tends to be relatively high or low compared to those who remain, is not clear a priori. To test for whether such simultaneity can explain the apparent relationship between outmigration and volatility, we estimate models that replace current with prerecession measures of labor-market quality. The intuition for this test (which we formalize in Appendix A) is that if the observed rela- tionship between migration and quality is entirely an artifact of simultaneity, the coefficient on lagged migration (which is determined before current volatility), will be zero.

Because correlation between current and lagged migration can transmit simultaneity to the coeffi- cient on the lag, this test is uninformative about the extent of bias due to simultaneity or, conse- quently, the magnitudes of the underlying causal effects. For most of our measures, however, it suggests that the previously observed relationship between volatility and outmigration cannot be explained away by simultaneity.

The tests implemented above suggest that neither reverse nor simultaneous causality explain our findings. demand for goods manufactured in the United States (say due to increased competition from abroad) might increase unemployment in a traditionally manufacturing-intense labor market, for example, although outmigration from that market is unlikely to have any effect on the national rate of manufacturing unemployment. Consequently, the instrument is neither simultaneously determined with local outmigration rates nor related to unobserved location 3 time-specific determinants of outmigration. These estimates provide strong evidence that neither simultaneity nor endogeneity drive our previous findings, especially for the high-skill group. In particular, when we control for lagged outmigration, the variation with which we identify the effect of volatility on migration is uncorrelated with factors that are idiosyncratic to labor markets at a given point in time (as a consequence of the instrument) as well as with factors that are common to a given labor market over time (as a consequence of the lag); the variation that remains is highly exogenous. Furthermore, the first-stage regressions presented in Table B1 of Appendix B show that in most cases the instruments strongly predict both the means and standard deviations of our quality measures, particularly for the high-skilled; this is true even when we included measures of lagged outmigration, which have considerable power to explain contemporaneous outmigration. For the low-skilled, some of the first-stage F-statistics are rela- tively small; this is potentially because local labor-market quality is more idiosyncratic, and hence the IV estimates less precise, for this group.

For the high-skill group, outmigration responds negatively to every measure of labor-market quality in every specification that we estimate and for each estimation method that we use. Our estimates evince a strong relationship between labor-market volatility and outmigration, and one that cannot be explained by simultaneous or reverse causality. The results are weaker and more specification-sensitive for the low-skill group, although this is consistent with descriptive evidence and findings from previous studies that less-skilled workers are not as mobile as their more edu- cated counterparts. Our instrumental variables estimates identify the impact of volatility on outmigration using national variation in labor-market quality that is plausibly exogenous to factors idiosyncratic to local labor markets, both within and across time. One challenge to this argument is that migration out of some metropolitan areas may respond to the national economic conditions that the instru- ment uses to predict local labor-market quality. To provide evidence against this interpretation, we run a falsification exercise in which we randomly match local skill groups to the Bartik-predicted quality facing members of the same skill group living in a different area. If the IV estimates reflected sensitivity to national economic conditions for some area 3 skill groups, on average we would expect outmigration in these groups to respond negatively to the quality facing a randomly selected group. The fourth set of estimates in Table 5 shows that this is not the case, further sugges- ting that our IV estimates identify the effects of volatility using variation that is otherwise exoge- nous to outmigration. Our focus on the Great Recession period increases the policy relevance of our analysis and allows us to exploit increased geographic variation in the quality and volatility of local labor- market quality. However, it also raises the question of whether the reduced outmigration that we observe in the data can be explained by recession-driven changes in housing prices. Of course, in order for changes in housing prices to explain away our findings, they would have to be correlated with the volatility of local labor-market quality. We have no prior reason to suspect a correlation between volatility and relative house prices and, at any rate, the instrumental variables estimate that we present above will have been purged of any such correlation. The Bartik instrumental variables strategy that we use in the previous section is premised on the notion that secular, nationwide shocks to the quality faced by workers in a given industry are exogenous to outmigration from any particular local labor market. A threat to this interpretation is that, since the national labor market is itself composed of many local labor markets, there will be a mechanical correlation between any local and national measures of labor market quality. To show that our IV estimates are not driven by such a correlation (which is likely to be small in any case), we follow Wozniak and Murray (2012) and Smith (2012) in instrumenting for quality in each metropolitan area using predictions obtained by excluding that area when computing national industry-specific quality measures. 24 The estimates, shown in the rightmost columns of

When the quality of labor market opportunities is declining on average over time, workers face a decision about whether to move in search of new opportunities. Moving, however, requires a substantial fixed cost. This cost includes not only the pecuniary costs of moving, but also the costs associated with leaving family, various amenities, and familiarity behind. Given the substan- tial fixed cost involved, we have developed a framework for thinking about this migration decision by drawing on work in the investment literature. Our framework treats migration as an optimal stopping problem in which workers must choose a threshold for labor market quality at which it is optimal to move. Our model implies that greater volatility in the quality of labor market opportu- nities reduces the likelihood of migration. We test this hypothesis by relating outmigration rates to multiple proxies for the level and vol- atility of labor market quality. Consistent with our theoretical model, we find that increases in the volatility of labor market quality reduce the likelihood of migration, regardless of how we measure quality or how we estimate its effects on migration. These results are robust to alternative, non- causal interpretations, and imply that outmigration rates from local labor markets would be con- siderably higher absent the inhibiting effects of volatility. Our findings lend credibility to the ability of our theoretical model to explain why relatively few people leave labor markets experienc- ing relative declines. Our model and results also suggest topics for further work. For example, while our theoreti- cal model assumes for the sake of simplicity that outside options are known with certainty, it is possible to amend the model to consider the role of uncertainty with regards to outside opportuni- ties. In addition to being interesting in its own right, extending the model in this way would permit sharper predictions about the internal migration response to different kinds of local quality shocks (e.g., if migration responds differently to a national recession, in which quality shocks are likely to be positively correlated across labor markets than it does to idiosyncratic local shocks that might induce a negative correlation). Our theoretical results may also have implications for internal migration policy, particularly if volatility reduces welfare by discouraging would-be migrants from paying the fixed costs required to obtain a better location match. We leave these suggestions for future research.
